To pare or cut off the surface of with a small knife; to cut or shape, as a piece of wood held in the hand, with a clasp knife or pocketknife.
The day following Whitmonday; -- called also Whitsun Tuesday.
A prejectile used in the Whitworth gun.
A form of rifled cannon and small arms invented by Sir Joseph Whitworth, of Manchester, England.

Originally, an interrogative pronoun, later, a relative pronoun also; -- used always substantively, and either as singular or plural.  See the Note under What, pron., 1.  As interrogative pronouns, who and whom ask the question: What or which person or persons? Who and whom, as relative pronouns (in the sense of that), are properly used of persons (corresponding to which, as applied to things), but are sometimes, less properly and now rarely, used of animals, plants, etc.  Who and whom, as compound relatives, are also used especially of persons, meaning the person that; the persons that; the one that; whosoever.
Containing the total amount, number, etc.; comprising all the parts; free from deficiency; all; total; entire; as, the whole earth; the whole solar system; the whole army; the whole nation.
Representing the whole figure; -- said of a picture or statue.
Sale of goods by the piece or large quantity, as distinguished from retail.
Extensive and indiscriminate; as, wholesale slaughter.
Tending to promote health; favoring health; salubrious; salutary.
In a whole or complete manner; entirely; completely; perfectly.
To the exclusion of other things; totally; fully.
To utter a whoop, or loud cry, as eagerness, enthusiasm, or enjoyment; to cry out; to shout; to halloo; to utter a war whoop; to hoot, as an owl.
One who, or that which, whops.
To have unlawful sexual intercourse; to practice lewdness.
The practice of unlawful intercourse with the other sex; fornication; lewdness.
One keeps or procures whores for others; a pimp; a procurer.
A whoremaster; a lecher; a man who frequents the society of whores.
A bastard; colloquially, a low, scurvy fellow; -- used generally in contempt, or in coarse humor. Also used adjectively.
A circle of two or more leaves, flowers, or other organs, about the same part or joint of a stem.
The whortleberry, or bilberry.  See Whortleberry (a).
The whortleberry, or bilberry.
The possessive case of who or which.  See Who, and Which.
To make a rough, humming sound, like one who pronounces the letter r with too much force; to whir; to birr.
To whisk along quickly; to hurry.
For what cause, reason, or purpose; on what account; wherefore; -- used interrogatively.  See the Note under What, pron., 1.
A violent and peremptory procedure without any assigned reason; a sudden conclusive happening.
A tribe of Indians native of the region between the Arkansas and Red rivers. They are related to the Pawnees.  See Pawnees.
A street; a village; a castle; a dwelling; a place of work, or exercise of authority; -- now obsolete except in composition; as, bailiwick, Warwick, Greenwick.

Evil in principle or practice; deviating from morality; contrary to the moral or divine law; addicted to vice or sin; sinful; immoral; profligate; -- said of persons and things; as, a wicked king; a wicked woman; a wicked deed; wicked designs.
A small pliant twig or osier; a rod for making basketwork and the like; a withe.

A small gate or door, especially one forming part of, or placed near, a larger door or gate; a narrow opening or entrance cut in or beside a door or gate, or the door which is used to close such entrance or aperture. Piers Plowman.
A rope or halter made of flexible twigs, or withes, as of birch.

Having considerable distance or extent between the sides; spacious across; much extended in a direction at right angles to that of length; not narrow; broad; as, wide cloth; a wide table; a wide highway; a wide bed; a wide hall or entry.
To a distance; far; widely; to a great distance or extent; as, his fame was spread wide.
That which goes wide, or to one side of the mark.
The angler; -- called also widegab, and widegut.
In a wide manner; to a wide degree or extent; far; extensively; as, the gospel was widely disseminated by the apostles.
Very much; to a great degree or extent; as, to differ widely in opinion.
To grow wide or wider; to enlarge; to spread; to extend.
Large extent in all directions; broadness; greatness; as, the wideness of the sea or ocean.
Widely; far and wide.
A woman who has lost her husband by death, and has not married again; one living bereaved of a husband.
To reduce to the condition of a widow; to bereave of a husband; -- rarely used except in the past participle.
A man who has lost his wife by death, and has not married again.
The state of being a widow; the time during which a woman is widow; also, rarely, the state of being a widower.
Estate settled on a widow.
One who makes widows by destroying husbands.
The quality of being wide; extent from side to side; breadth; wideness; as, the width of cloth; the width of a door.
Of or pertaining to a widow; vidual.
To govern; to rule; to keep, or have in charge; also, to possess.
The act or power of wielding.
A woman; an adult female; -- now used in literature only in certain compounds and phrases, as alewife, fishwife, goodwife, and the like.

A covering for the head, consisting of hair interwoven or united by a kind of network, either in imitation of the natural growth, or in abundant and flowing curls, worn to supply a deficiency of natural hair, or for ornament, or according to traditional usage, as a part of an official or professional dress, the latter especially in England by judges and barristers.

A kind of canvaslike cotton fabric, used to stiffen and protect the lower part of trousers and of the skirts of women's dresses, etc.; -- so called from Wigan, the name of a town in Lancashire, England.
A kind of raised seedcake.
A wig or wigs; false hair.
Any cover or screen, as red-tapism.
Act of wiggling; a wriggle.
The young, either larva or pupa, of the mosquito; -- called also wiggletail.
To neigh; to whinny.
A whit; a bit; a jot.
Having or wearing no wig.
To signal by means of a flag waved from side to side according to a code adopted for the purpose.
An Indian cabin or hut, usually of a conical form, and made of a framework of poles covered with hides, bark, or mats; -- called also tepee.
A home; a dwelling.

Living in a state of nature; inhabiting natural haunts, as the forest or open field; not familiar with, or not easily approached by, man; not tamed or domesticated; as, a wild boar; a wild ox; a wild cat.
Running without control; running along the line without a train; as, a wild-cat locomotive.
The state of being bewildered; confusion; bewilderment.
A tract of land, or a region, uncultivated and uninhabited by human beings, whether a forest or a wide, barren plain; a wild; a waste; a desert; a pathless waste of any kind.
An old name for erysipelas.
The quality or state of being wild; an uncultivated or untamed state; disposition to rove or go unrestrained; rudeness; savageness; irregularity; distraction.
A wild or unfrequented wood. Also used adjectively; as, wildwood flowers; wildwood echoes.
To draw or turn away, as by diversion; to while or while away; to cause to pass pleasantly.
See Willful, Willfully, and Willfulness.
The quality or state of being wily; craftiness; cunning; guile.

The power of choosing; the faculty or endowment of the soul by which it is capable of choosing; the faculty or power of the mind by which we decide to do or not to do; the power or faculty of preferring or selecting one of two or more objects.
To wish; to desire; to incline to have.
To form a distinct volition of; to determine by an act of choice; to ordain; to decree.
A large North American snipe (Symphemia semipalmata); -- called also pill-willet, will-willet, semipalmated tattler, or snipe, duck snipe, and stone curlew.
Of set purpose; self-determined; voluntary; as, willful murder.
Free to do or to grant; having the mind inclined; not opposed in mind; not choosing to refuse; disposed; not averse; desirous; consenting; complying; ready.

Any tree or shrub of the genus Salix, including many species, most of which are characterized often used as an emblem of sorrow, desolation, or desertion. "A wreath of willow to show my forsaken plight." Sir W. Scott. Hence, a lover forsaken by, or having lost, the person beloved, is said to wear the willow.
Abounding with willows; containing willows; covered or overgrown with willows.
A perennial herb (Epilobium spicatum) with narrow willowlike leaves and showy rose-purple flowers. The name is sometimes made to include other species of the same genus.
A European species of loosestrife (Lysimachia vulgaris).
Resembling a willow; pliant; flexible; pendent; drooping; graceful.
A large wicker basket.
To wish; to desire.
To begin to wither; to lose freshness and become flaccid, as a plant when exposed when exposed to drought, or to great heat in a dry day, or when separated from its root; to droop;. to wither.
To cause to begin to wither; to make flaccid, as a green plant.
Hence, to cause to languish; to depress or destroy the vigor and energy of.
To bore or pierce, as with a wimble.
A covering of silk, linen, or other material, for the neck and chin, formerly worn by women as an outdoor protection, and still retained in the dress of nuns.
To clothe with a wimple; to cover, as with a veil; hence, to hoodwink.
To gain by superiority in competition or contest; to obtain by victory over competitors or rivals; as, to win the prize in a gate; to win money; to win a battle, or to win a country.
To shrink, as from a blow, or from pain; to flinch; to start back.
A reel used in dyeing, steeping, or washing cloth; a winch. It is placed over the division wall between two wince pits so as to allow the cloth to descend into either compartment. at will.
To wince; to shrink; to kick with impatience or uneasiness.
A kick, as of a beast, from impatience or uneasiness.
A crank with a handle, for giving motion to a machine, a grindstone, etc.

To turn completely, or with repeated turns; especially, to turn about something fixed; to cause to form convolutions about anything; to coil; to twine; to twist; to wreathe; as, to wind thread on a spool or into a ball.
To have a circular course or direction; to crook; to bend; to meander; as, to wind in and out among trees.
Air naturally in motion with any degree of velocity; a current of air.
To expose to the wind; to winnow; to ventilate.
The difference between the diameter of the bore of a gun and that of the shot fired from it.
To break the wind of; to cause to lose breath; to exhaust.

Having the power of breathing impaired by the rupture, dilatation, or running together of air cells of the lungs, so that while the inspiration is by one effort, the expiration is by two; affected with pulmonary emphysema or with heaves; -- said of a horse.
One who, or that which, winds; hence, a creeping or winding plant.
A blow taking away the breath.
To wither; to fail.
An unexpected legacy, or other gain.
Anemophilous; fertilized by pollen borne by the wind.
The anemone; -- so called because formerly supposed to open only when the wind was blowing.  See Anemone.
A soft tumor or synovial swelling on the fetlock joint of a horse; -- so called from having formerly been supposed to contain air.
The kestrel; -- called also windbibber, windcuffer, windfanner.
The quality or state of being windy or tempestuous; as, the windiness of the weather or the season.
Fullness of wind; flatulence.
Twisting from a direct line or an even surface; circuitous.
To take a roundabout course; to work warily or by indirect means.

A machine for raising weights, consisting of a horizontal cylinder or roller moving on its axis, and turned by a crank, lever, or similar means, so as to wind up a rope or chain attached to the weight. In vessels the windlass is often used instead of the capstan for raising the anchor. It is usually set upon the forecastle, and is worked by hand or steam.
A spindle; a kind of reel; a winch.
Wanting wind; out of breath.

An opening in the wall of a building for the admission of light and air, usually closed by casements or sashes containing some transparent material, as glass, and capable of being opened and shut at pleasure.
To furnish with windows.

A thin, spotted American turbot (Pleuronectes maculatus) remarkable for its translucency. It is not valued as a food fish. Called also spotted turbot, daylight, spotted sand flounder, and water flounder.
Caused to ride or drive by the wind in opposition to the course of the tide; -- said of a vessel lying at anchor, with wind and tide opposed to each other.
A row or line of hay raked together for the purpose of being rolled into cocks or heaps.
(Far.) A horse given to wind-sucking
So tight as to prevent the passing through of wind.
Toward the wind; in the direction from which the wind blows.
Consisting of wind; accompanied or characterized by wind; exposed to wind.
The expressed juice of grapes, esp. when fermented; a beverage or liquor prepared from grapes by squeezing out their juice, and (usually) allowing it to ferment.
One who drinks much wine.
A small glass from to drink wine.
As much as a wineglass will hold; enough to fill a wineglass. It is usually reckoned at two fluid ounces, or four tablespoonfuls.
destitute of wine; as, wineless life.
A place where grapes are converted into wine.

One of the two anterior limbs of a bird, pterodactyl, or bat. They correspond to the arms of man, and are usually modified for flight, but in the case of a few species of birds, as the ostrich, auk, etc., the wings are used only as an assistance in running or swimming.
Soaring with wings, or as if with wings; hence, elevated; lofty; sublime.
Having wings attached to the feet; as, wing-footed Mercury; hence, swift; moving with rapidity; fleet.
Having part or all of the feet adapted for flying.
Having pinnate or pinnately divided leaves.
Having no wings; not able to ascend or fly.
A bastard wing, or alula.
Soaring with wings, or as if with wings; volatile airy.
To nod; to sleep; to nap.
The act of closing, or closing and opening, the eyelids quickly; hence, the time necessary for such an act; a moment.
A horse's blinder; a blinker.
A tribe of North American Indians who originally occupied the region about Green Bay, Lake Michigan, but were driven back from the lake and nearly exterminated in 1640 by the IIlinnois.
One who wins, or gains by success in competition, contest, or gaming.
Attracting; adapted to gain favor; charming; as, a winning address.
The money, etc., gained by success in competition or contest, esp, in gambling; -- usually in the plural.
The quality or state of being winning.
To separate, and drive off, the chaff from by means of wind; to fan; as, to winnow grain.
The act of one who, or that which, winnows.
Cheerful; merry; gay; light-hearted.
The season of the year in which the sun shines most obliquely upon any region; the coldest season of the year.
Beaten or harassed by the severe weather of winter.
Like winter; wintry; cold; hence, disagreeable, cheerless; as, winterly news.

The aromatic bark of tree (Drimys, ∨ Drymis, Winteri) of the Magnolia family, which is found in Southern Chili. It was first used as a cure for scurvy by its discoverer, Captain John Winter, vice admiral to sir Francis Drake, in 1577.
Suitable to winter; resembling winter, or what belongs to winter; brumal; hyemal; cold; stormy; wintery.
To rub with something soft for cleaning; to clean or dry by rubbing; as, to wipe the hands or face with a towel.
A blow; a stroke; a hit; a swipe.
Something used for wiping, as a towel or rag.
A thread or slender rod of metal; a metallic substance formed to an even thread by being passed between grooved rollers, or drawn through holes in a plate of steel.
To put upon a wire; as, to wire beads.
To send a telegraphic message.
To form (a piece of metal) into wire, by drawing it through a hole in a plate of steel.
A disease in the feet of a horse or other beast.
One who pulls the wires, as of a puppet; hence, one who operates by secret means; an intriguer.
Having some or all of the tail quills terminated in a long, slender, pointed shaft, without a web or barbules.
Work, especially openwork, formed of wires.
One who manufactures articles from wire.

One of the larv\'91 of various species of snapping beetles, or elaters; -- so called from their slenderness and the uncommon hardness of the integument.  Wireworms are sometimes very destructive to the roots of plants.  Called also wire grub.
The quality of being wiry.
Made of wire; like wire; drawn out like wire.
The quality of being wise; knowledge, and the capacity to make due use of it; knowledge of the best ends and the best means; discernment and judgment; discretion; sagacity; skill; dexterity.
Having knowledge; knowing; enlightened; of extensive information; erudite; learned.
A learned or wise man.
To have a desire or yearning; to long; to hanker.
Expression of desire; request; petition; hence, invocation or imprecation.
According to wish; conformably to desire.
Showing desire; as, wishful eyes.
Any weak, thin drink.
Thin and pale; weak; without strength or substance; -- originally said of liquids. Fig., weak-minded; spiritless.
A whisket, or basket.
A small bundle, as of straw or other like substance.
To brush or dress, an with a wisp.
To show; to teach; to inform; to guide; to direct.
A genus of climbing leguminous plants bearing long, pendulous clusters of pale bluish flowers.
To know; to learn.
Mind; intellect; understanding; sense.

One who practices the black art, or magic; one regarded as possessing supernatural or magical power by compact with an evil spirit, esp. with the Devil; a sorcerer or sorceress; -- now applied chiefly or only to women, but formerly used of men as well.
The practices or art of witches; sorcery; enchantments; intercourse with evil spirits.
That witches or enchants; suited to enchantment or witchcraft; bewitching.
The sand martin, or bank swallow.
One who breaks jests; a joker.
The art of reasoning; logic.
With denotes or expresses some situation or relation of nearness, proximity, association, connection, or the like.
To denote a close or direct relation of opposition or hostility; -- equivalent to against.
With this; with that.
To take back or away, as what has been bestowed or enjoyed; to draw back; to cause to move away or retire; as, to withdraw aid, favor, capital, or the like.
A room for retirement from another room, as from a dining room; a drawing-room.
A flexible, slender twig or branch used as a band; a willow or osier twig; a withy.
To fade; to lose freshness; to become sapless; to become sapless; to dry or shrivel up.
To cause to shrink, wrinkle, or decay, for want of animal moisture.
Faded; dried up; shriveled; wilted; wasted; wasted away.
Barium carbonate occurring in white or gray six-sided twin crystals, and also in columnar or granular masses.
A withered person; one who is decrepit.
The ridge between the shoulder bones of a horse, at the base of the neck.  See Illust. of Horse.
To hold back; to restrain; to keep from action.
The act of withholding.
In the inner or interior part of; inside of; not without; as, within doors.
On or at the outside of; out of; not within; as, without doors.
Outside of the house; out of doors.
A kind of bindweed (Convolvulus arvensis).
The osier willow (Salix viminalis).  See Osier, n. (a).
Attestation of a fact or an event; testimony.
To see or know by personal presence; to have direct cognizance of.
One who affects repartee; a wit-cracker.
Knowingly; with knowledge; by design.
Possessed of wit; knowing; wise; skillful; judicious; clever; cunning.
One who, or that which, feeds on or destroys wit.
To take for a wife; to marry.
A fabulous two-legged, winged creature, like a cockatrice, but having the head of a dragon, and without spurs.
A wise man; a sage.
The character or practices o<?/ wizards; sorcery; magic.
Wizened; thin; weazen; withered.
Dried; shriveled; withered; shrunken; weazen; as, a wizened old man.
Having a shriveled, thin, withered face.
An herbaceous cruciferous plant (Isatis tinctoria). It was formerly cultivated for the blue coloring matter derived from its leaves.
Mad.  See Wood, a.
Grief; sorrow; misery; heavy calamity.
The quality or state of being woeful; misery; wretchedness.
A wood; a forest.
imp. of Will.  See Would.

Any one of several species of wild and savage carnivores belonging to the genus Canis and closely allied to the common dog. The best-known and most destructive species are the European wolf (Canis lupus), the American gray, or timber, wolf (C. occidentalis), and the prairie wolf, or coyote. Wolves often hunt in packs, and may thus attack large animals and even man.
Discovered, or first described, by Caspar Friedrich Wolff (1733-1794), the founder of modern embryology.
Of or pertaining to wolframium.  See Tungstic.

Tungstate of iron and manganese, generally of a brownish or grayish black color, submetallic luster, and high specific gravity. It occurs in cleavable masses, and also crystallized. Called also wolfram.
The technical name of the element tungsten.  See Tungsten.
A kind of club moss.  See Lycopodium.
Club moss.  See Lycopodium.
Any kind of spurge (Euphorbia); -- so called from its acrid milky juice.
A silicate of lime of a white to gray, red, or yellow color, occurring generally in cleavable masses, rarely in tabular crystals; tabular spar.
An adult female person; a grown-up female person, as distinguished from a man or a child; sometimes, any female person.
To make effeminate or womanish.
Like a woman; womanly.
The belly; the abdomen.
imp. & p. p. of Win.
To dwell or abide.

That emotion which is excited by novelty, or the presentation to the sight or mind of something new, unusual, strange, great, extraordinary, or not well understood; surprise; astonishment; admiration; amazement.
To be affected with surprise or admiration; to be struck with astonishment; to be amazed; to marvel.
Adapted to excite wonder or admiration; surprising; strange; astonishing.
A land full of wonders, or marvels.
Doing wonders or surprising things.
In a wonderful or surprising manner or degree; wonderfully.
To solicit in love; to court.
A large and thick collection of trees; a forest or grove; -- frequently used in the plural.

A process in photographic printing, in which a relief pattern in gelatin, which has been hardened after certain operations, is pressed upon a plate of lead or other soft metal. An intaglio impression in thus produced, from which pictures may be directly printed, but by a slower process than in common printing.

A common large North American marmot (Arctomys monax). It is usually reddish brown, more or less grizzled with gray. It makes extensive burrows, and is often injurious to growing crops. Called also ground hog.
The yaffle, or green woodpecker.
Any one of several species of long-billed limicoline birds belonging to the genera Scolopax and Philohela. They are mostly nocturnal in their habits, and are highly esteemed as game birds.
Skill and practice in anything pertaining to the woods, especially in shooting, and other sports in the woods.
A person who cuts wood.
An engraver on wood.
The act or art of engraving on wood.
Clumsy; awkward; ungainly; stiff; spiritless.
A place where wood is stored.
A house or shed in which wood is stored, and sheltered from the weather.
The quality or state of being woody.
Land covered with wood or trees; forest; land on which trees are suffered to grow, either for fuel or timber.
A young oak, or other timber plant, laid down in a hedge among the whitethorn or other plants used in hedges.
Having no wood; destitute of wood.
In a wood, mad, or raving manner; madly; furiously.
A forest officer appointed to take care of the king's woods; a forester.
Anger; madness; insanity; rage.
Any one of numerous species of scansorial birds belonging to Picus and many allied genera of the family Picid\'91.
A little European herb (Asperula odorata) having a pleasant taste. It is sometimes used for flavoring wine.  See Illust. of Whorl.
A kind of froth seen on herbs.
The time when there no sap in the trees; the winter season.
A fusible alloy consisting of one or two parts of cadmium, two parts of tin, four of lead, with seven or eight part of bismuth. It melts at from 66° to 71° C.  See Fusible metal, under Fusible.
A striped variety of hornstone, resembling wood in appearance.
Of or pertaining to the woods or forest.
An officer of the forest, whose duty it was to guard the woods.
A genus of ferns, one species of which (Woodwardia radicans) is a showy plant in California, the Azores, etc.
Work made of wood; that part of any structure which is wrought of wood.
Abounding with wood or woods; as, woody land.
The threads that cross the warp in a woven fabric; the weft; the filling; the thread usually carried by the shuttle in weaving.
In a wooing manner; enticingly; with persuasiveness.

The soft and curled, or crisped, species of hair which grows on sheep and some other animals, and which in fineness sometimes approaches to fur; -- chiefly applied to the fleecy coat of the sheep, which constitutes a most essential material of clothing in all cold and temperate climates.
One of the handles of the top, formed by a wooden pin passing through it.  See 1st Top, 2.
Dyed before being made into cloth, in distinction from piece-dyed; ingrain.
Having (such) wool; as, a fine-wooled sheep.
Made of wool; consisting of wool; as, woolen goods.
A thin, light fabric of wool.
A skin with the wool; a skin from which the wool has not been sheared or pulled.
Indulging in a vagrant or idle exercise of the imagination; roaming upon a fruitless quest; idly fanciful.
Indulgence in idle imagination; a foolish or useless pursuit or design.
A trade market in the woolen districts.
The quality or state of being woolly.
Consisting of wool; as, a woolly covering; a woolly fleece.
Resembling wool; of the nature of wool.
One who deals in wool.
A pack or bag of wool weighing two hundred and forty pounds.
A sack or bag of wool; specifically, the seat of the lord chancellor of England in the House of Lords, being a large, square sack of wool resembling a divan in form.
A heavy wooden hammer for milling cloth.
In wool; with woolen raiment next the skin.
A wearing of woolen clothes next the skin as a matter of penance.

The spoken sign of a conception or an idea; an articulate or vocal sound, or a combination of articulate and vocal sounds, uttered by the human voice, and by custom expressing an idea or ideas; a single component part of human speech or language; a constituent part of a sentence; a term; a vocable.
To express in words; to phrase.
One who cavils at words.
The quality or state of being wordy, or abounding with words; verboseness.
Of or pertaining to words; consisting of words; verbal; as, a wordy war.
Exertion of strength or faculties; physical or intellectual effort directed to an end; industrial activity; toil; employment; sometimes, specifically, physically labor.
To exert one's self for a purpose; to put forth effort for the attainment of an object; to labor; to be engaged in the performance of a task, a duty, or the like.

To produce or form by labor; to bring forth by exertion or toil; to accomplish; to originate; to effect; as, to work wood or iron into a form desired, or into a utensil; to work cotton or wool into cloth.
A bag for holding implements or materials for work; especially, a reticule, or bag for holding needlework, and the like.
A basket for holding materials for needlework, or the like.
A bench on which work is performed, as in a carpenter's shop.
A box for holding instruments or materials for work.
A day on which work is performed, as distinguished from Sunday, festivals, etc., a working day.
One who, or that which, works; a laborer; a performer; as, a worker in brass.

One of the neuter, or sterile, individuals of the social ants, bees, and white ants. The workers are generally females having the sexual organs imperfectly developed.  See Ant, and White ant, under White.
Full of work; diligent.
A house where any manufacture is carried on; a workshop.
Without work; not laboring; as, many people were still workless.
Not carried out in practice; not exemplified in fact; as, workless faith.
A man employed in labor, whether in tillage or manufactures; a worker.
Becoming a skillful workman; skillful; well performed; workmanlike.
In a skillful manner; in a manner becoming a skillful workman.
A shop where any manufacture or handiwork is carried on.
A table for holding working materials and implements; esp., a small table with drawers and other conveniences for needlework, etc.
A woman who performs any work; especially, a woman skilled in needlework.
A week day or working day, as distinguished from Sunday or a holiday. Also used adjectively.
The earth and the surrounding heavens; the creation; the system of created things; existent creation; the universe.
A person whose soul is set upon gaining temporal possessions; one devoted to this world and its enjoyments.
Relating to the world; human; common; as, worldly maxims; worldly actions.
Extended throughout the world; as, world-wide fame.
A creeping or a crawling animal of any kind or size, as a serpent, caterpillar, snail, or the like.
Eaten, or eaten into, by a worm or by worms; as, worm-eaten timber.
A burrow made by a worm.
Discovered or described by Olanus Wormius, a Danish anatomist.

Any botfly larva which burrows in or beneath the skin of domestic and wild animals, thus producing sores. They belong to various species of Hypoderma and allied genera. Domestic cattle are often infested by a large species.  See Gadfly. Called also warble, and worble.
Any species of Vermetus.

A composite plant (Artemisia Absinthium), having a bitter and slightly aromatic taste, formerly used as a tonic and a vermifuge, and to protect woolen garments from moths. It gives the peculiar flavor to the cordial called absinthe. The volatile oil is a narcotic poison. The term is often extended to other species of the same genus.
Containing a worm; abounding with worms.
Consumed, or rendered useless, by wearing; as, worn-out garments.
An Egyptian fork-tongued lizard, about four feet long when full grown.
Inclined to worry or fret; also, causing worry or annoyance.
To worry; to annoy.
To harass by pursuit and barking; to attack repeatedly; also, to tear or mangle with the teeth.
A state of undue solicitude; a state of disturbance from care and anxiety; vexation; anxiety; fret; as, to be in a worry.
Bad, ill, evil, or corrupt, in a greater degree; more bad or evil; less good; specifically, in poorer health; more sick; -- used both in a physical and moral sense.
That which is worse; something less good; as, think not the worse of him for his enterprise.
To get the better of; to worst.
Excellence of character; dignity; worth; worthiness.
To respect; to honor; to treat with civil reverence.
Entitled to worship, reverence, or high respect; claiming respect; worthy of honor; -- often used as a term of respect, sometimes ironically.
Well-twisted yarn spun of long-staple wool which has been combed to lay the fibers parallel, used for carpets, cloth, hosiery, gloves, and the like.
A plant of any kind.
Valuable; of worthy; estimable; also, worth while.

That quality of a thing which renders it valuable or useful; sum of valuable qualities which render anything useful and sought; value; hence, often, value as expressed in a standard, as money; equivalent in exchange; price.
Having worth or excellence; possessing merit; valuable; deserving; estimable; excellent; virtuous.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Wit, to know.
\'b7 (as, a would-be poet\'3c-- wannabe--\'3e.
Emotion of desire; inclination; velleity.
A kind of wash bottle with two or three necks; -- so called after the inventor, Peter Woulfe, an English chemist.
imp. & p. p. of Wind to twist, and Wind to sound by blowing.
A hurt or injury caused by violence; specifically, a breach of the skin and flesh of an animal, or in the substance of any creature or living thing; a cut, stab, rent, or the like.
To hurt by violence; to produce a breach, or separation of parts, in, as by a cut, stab, blow, or the like.
In a woundy manner; excessively; woundy.
Free from wound or hurt; exempt from being wounded; invulnerable.
The agile, or silvery, gibbon; -- called also camper.  See Gibbon.
p. pr. & rare vb. n. of Weave.
p. p. of Weave.
To rack; to torment.
An apparition of a person in his exact likeness, seen before death, or a little after; hence, an apparition; a specter; a vision; an unreal image.
To argue; to debate; to dispute.

One of those who stand in the first rank of honors in the University of Cambridge, England. They are called, according to their rank, senior wrangler, second wrangler, third wrangler, etc. Cf. Optime.
To snatch up; transport; -- chiefly used in the p. p. wrapt.
To wind or fold together; to arrange in folds.
The act of wrapping.
That which wraps; envelope; covering.
That in which anything is wrapped, or inclosed; envelope; covering.

Any one of numerous edible, marine, spiny-finned fishes of the genus Labrus, of which several species are found in the Mediterranean and on the Atlantic coast of Europe. Many of the species are bright-colored.
Violent anger; vehement exasperation; indignation; rage; fury; ire.
To anger; to enrage; -- also used impersonally.
Springing from, or expressing, wrath; as, a wrathful countenance.
Free from anger or wrath.
To revenge; to avenge.
Something twisted, intertwined, or curled; as, a wreath of smoke; a wreath of flowers.
To cause to revolve or writhe; to twist about; to turn.
A marine shell of the genus Turbo.  See Turbo.
Wreathed; twisted; curled; spiral; also, full of wreaths.
The destruction or injury of a vessel by being cast on shore, or on rocks, or by being disabled or sunk by the force of winds or waves; shipwreck.
To destroy, disable, or seriously damage, as a vessel, by driving it against the shore or on rocks, by causing it to become unseaworthy, to founder, or the like; to shipwreck.
To work upon a wreck, as in saving property or lives, or in plundering.
That which has been wrecked; remains of a wreck.

One who searches fro, or works upon, the wrecks of vessels, etc. Specifically: (a) One who visits a wreck for the purpose of plunder. (b) One who is employed in saving property or lives from a wrecked vessel, or in saving the vessel; as, the wreckers of Key West.
Causing wreck; involving ruin; destructive.
Any one of numerous species of small singing birds belonging to Troglodytes and numerous allied of the family Troglodytid\'91.
Trick; deceit; fraud; stratagem.
To pull with a twist; to wrest, twist, or force by violence.
To turn; to twist; esp., to twist or extort by violence; to pull of force away by, or as if by, violent wringing or twisting.
Active or moving power.
To contend, by grappling with, and striving to trip or throw down, an opponent; as, they wrestled skillfully.
A struggle between two persons to see which will throw the other down; a bout at wrestling; a wrestling match; a struggle.
A miserable person; one profoundly unhappy.
The quality or state of being wretched; utter misery.
A wretched object; anything despicably.
To twist and compress; to turn and strain with violence; to writhe; to squeeze hard; to pinch; as, to wring clothes in washing.
One who, or that which, wrings; hence, an extortioner.
A machine for pressing water out of anything, particularly from clothes after they have been washed.
A small ridge, prominence, or furrow formed by the shrinking or contraction of any smooth substance; a corrugation; a crease; a slight fold; as, wrinkle in the skin; a wrinkle in cloth.
To contract into furrows and prominences; to make a wrinkle or wrinkles in; to corrugate; as, wrinkle the skin or the brow.
Full of wrinkles; having a tendency to be wrinkled; corrugated; puckered.
The joint, or the region of the joint, between the hand and the arm; the carpus.  See Carpus.
A covering for the wrist.
An elastic band worn around the wrist, as for the purpose of securing the upper part of a glove.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Write, for writeth.
That which is written; writing; scripture; -- applied especially to the Scriptures, or the books of the Old and New testaments; as, sacred writ.
Inclined to much writing; -- correlative to talkative.
To set down, as legible characters; to form the conveyance of meaning; to inscribe on any material by a suitable instrument; as, to write the characters called letters; to write figures.
One who writes, or has written; a scribe; a clerk.
To twist; to turn; now, usually, to twist or turn so as to distort; to wring.
Anything written or printed; anything expressed in characters or letters
Twisted; wry; as, a wrong nose.
To treat with injustice; to deprive of some right, or to withhold some act of justice from; to do undeserved harm to; to deal unjustly with; to injure.
One who commits a tort or trespass; a trespasser; a tort feasor.
One who wrongs or injures another.
A person of a perverse understanding or obstinate character.
Constituting, or of the nature of, a wrong; unjust; wrongful.
imp. of Write. Wrote.
Full of wrath; angry; incensed; much exasperated; wrathful.
Turned to one side; twisted; distorted; as, a wry mouth.
To deviate from the right way; to go away or astray; to turn side; to swerve.
Any one of several species of large, elongated, marine fishes of the genus Cryptacanthodes, especially C. maculatus of the American coast. A whitish variety is called ghostfish.
A twisted or distorted neck; a deformity in which the neck is drawn to one side by a rigid contraction of one of the muscles of the neck; torticollis.
The quality or state of being wry, or distorted.
Native lead molybdate occurring in tetragonal crystals, usually tabular, and of a bright orange-yellow to red, gray, or brown color; -- also called yellow lead ore.
A fruit bat (Pteropus medius) native of India. It is similar to the flying fox, but smaller.
The Australian white-quilled honey eater (Entomyza albipennis).
A species of elm (Ulmus montana) found in Northern and Western Europe; Scotch elm.
A follower of Wyclif, the English reformer; a Lollard.
A narrow lane or alley.
A kind of timber truck, or carriage.
The wipe, or lapwing.
Same as Withe, n., 4.
